7.content:
IMPORTANT INFORMATION

In the next part of this study you will try to earn points by successfully completing bubble-clicking tasks. This involves clicking all of the bubbles within the allotted time.

Successfully clicking all bubbles in a trial earns you points.
Failing to click all bubbles in a trial costs you points.

Before each bubble task you will select which task option you will attempt to complete.

To help you choose between the task options you will be provided with some information about each of the task options.

Before you begin we will show you all the important parts of the task. Please read this information carefully.

Click to continue.

17.content:
IMPORTANT INFORMATION

Your goal is to earn as many points as you can.

If you click all of the bubbles you earn points.
If you do not click all of the bubbles you lose points.
Try to choose the best task for earning points.

The details of the tasks change from trial to trial.
The only way to pick the best task is by understanding what the symbols tell you about how the tasks compare in that particular trial.

To select the best task, pay attention to the SOURCE task and symbols that appear along the arrow between each option. Use the information provided to select the best task to complete to earn points.

In the beginning picking the best task will involve some trial and error. Please be patient and try your best to select and complete the best task.

You will see after each task if you earned points and how many points you have.

Good luck!

Click to continue.

messageHandlers.code:
time = Math.round(timerWidth/(100/time))
remaining = circles.length
bubblesClicked = number - remaining

if (remaining >= 1) {
  score = score - points
  trialScore = - points
  acc = 0
  setPoint -= 2
  failure = 1
} else if (remaining <= 0) {
  score = score + points
  trialScore = points
  acc = 1
  passedCalibration = 1
};

accSeq.push(acc)
accSeq.length > 20 ? (currentAccSeq = accSeq.slice(-20)):(currentAccSeq = accSeq)
criterion = currentAccSeq.reduce(add)
rtSeq.push(Math.round(this.state.duration))

this.data.choice = choice
this.data.number = number
this.data.setPoint = setPoint
this.data.size = size
this.data.speed = speed
this.data.remaining = remaining
this.data.score = score

adjustment = setPoint - Number(this.parameters.number)
timerWidth = 100
clearFrames();

30.content:
Study guidelines


Make sure you do this experiment on a laptop or regular desktop computer and NOT on a smartphone or tablet. You will need a keyboard and mouse for this experiment.

Do not close this tab and do not switch to other tabs during the experiment. It is important that you remain attentive. In this way you help us to make this research valuable.

This study will last approximately 60 minutes. You will be paid for your participation in the study.

In this study you will learn how to complete some tasks. You will see a sequence of screens. On some screens you must respond by using your mouse to click as many bubbles as you can. On other screens you will select task options using your mouse. Sometimes you will be provided with feedback for your response - but not always!

Learn how to click the bubbles to earn points. Then select tasks to click bubbles and earn as many points as you can.


Press space to continue
30.title: guidelines

31.content:
Informed Consent

You may need to scroll down to see all the text on this screen.

Project Title: Learning

Overview and Procedures: The purpose of this study is to investigate how we learn. You will see screens with containing symbols. Sometimes you will need to respond to what is presented on screen.

Risk and Benefits. This study involves no more risk to your physical or psychological health beyond those encountered in the normal course of everyday life. You may benefit by gaining a better understanding of psychological research. No other risks or benefits are anticipated.

Confidentiality. Any information obtained in this study will be kept strictly confidential and used solely for research purposes. We do not ask any identifying information and responses will be kept completely anonymous. Your anonymised data may be posted to a public repository for other researchers to make use of.

Compensation. You will receive a sum of money for participating.

Your Rights. Your decision to participate in this research is voluntary. You can withdraw from the study at any time without penalty. You do not have to answer any questions you do not want to.

Contact Information. If you have any questions or issues with this study please contact the principle investigator (Martin Finn) at martin.finn@ugent.be who can review the matter and provide further information.

You must be 18 years of age or older to participate in this research study.

Please let the experimenter know if you would like a copy of this form for your records.

If you want to continue press the button.
31.title: informedConsent

32.content:
Please provide the following information

Age
Gender
Prolific ID

47.title: followupQuestions

48.content:
Debriefing

Thank you for completing the study!

You may need to scroll down to see all the text on this screen.

The purpose of this study is to investigate how we learn. At the beginning we assessed how many bubbles you could click. Then we presented you with a series of choices between tasks. The differences between the tasks were communicated by the symbols appearing between them. You were asked to try select the best task for earning points. On each trial you were shown what the SOURCE task would look like. You could select and complete other tasks. By comparing these tasks the meaning of the new symbols might have become clear. You might have noticed that the symbols signified "more bubbles", "less bubbles", "more points", and "less points". You may not have noticed this, and that is the reason for this study.

The specific purpose of this study was to discover whether the training we provided allowed the symbols to communicate information about the bubbles tasks. If the easiest tasks offering the most points were selected consistently then the symbols used in this study did indeed operate as symbols.

There is a more general purpose too. As described above, the final part of the study involves multiple symbols and interactions between them. We are constantly interacting with symbols (e.g., words, numbers, road-signs etc). Our more general purpose is to discover how we learn to respond appropriately to symbols and the interactions between them. I hope that makes things clear! If you have any questions about the study you can email me at martin.finn@ugent.be

Click to continue.
48.title: debrief

50.title: endScreen
50.content:
Thank you!

Please click here to indicate that you finished the study.
